5_1ADB7TdX2fVbTsWBoMe9yBTmVXTbb33b4R.body:
Try using it with tor.

Tor+zeronet = using TCP. (tor blocks all UDP connections too, so zeronet should use that)

If your school is blocking tor try using something like bridges and if that fails then try obfs. I am asking that you try it in that order, if you do not know what methods your school is using to block traffic. It might be something simple if they fail then you can start the cat/mouse game that is bridges and obfs proxies.

How to get bridges? 
web: https://bridges.torproject.org/options
email: https://bridges.torproject.org/howto

Tor OBFS how?
https://www.torproject.org/projects/obfsproxy

Its showing up as 54 MB for me now. Then again, I've been offline for IDK how long.

It is possible for some files to be slightly different sizes. My terminal will at times complain that hashes do not match file content but IDK, it could be about something else.

Generally speaking I know that if a hash test fails, file "a" is different from file "b" but it does not specify file size. The difference could be a little as like a few byte or hundreds of gigabytes.

1_14hiNi2B2XEnvPSwetWUfzimNXQ1Keahnm.body:
I say put this near public transportation or even public places such as libraries. I hear that some libraries love hosting tor nodes, may be you can also get them to host a few zeronet nodes, so that way people can see whats on zeronet at the library AND the network gets more stable nodes.

Granted zeronet is redundant and reliable already, a few more never hurt. Especially with some of these libraries with high network speeds.

3_19M1DT5vruSATEcbEczYRwCk2uPuLcATBa.body:
You can make your own private proxy.

eg. Nginx or Apache + .htaccess + reverse proxy to your local zero net IP/port = mobile zeronet

eg. SSH tunnels + port forwarding = remote zeronet

eg. Hidden service/eepsite forward to zeronet IP/port = seekret mobile zeronet

These options do require some googling but they are relatively easy if you use command line once in a while.

> [talnicrom](#comment_24_19M1DT5vruSATEcbEczYRwCk2uPuLcATBa): See my reply to ks down the page.

No offense but my solutions work also and some are more secure anyways.

ah wait you want a mobile Zeronet?

Yeah there is a problem with using a bunch of mobile devices are routers, relay, or torrent seeds...

Uptime, throughput, and laziness.

Uptime: many mobile devices will be shut down and have "intermittent" connections

Throughput: many mobile devices suck butt when it comes to providing a decent speed to get file "x"

Laziness: people always get bored and uninstall shit.

Source: see I2P on mobile devices, they use them in the I2P network but not as floodfills or high capacity nodes. IDR what the hell they use them for but they are playing around with it.

In apps like Zeronet using short lived and slow nodes is hard to find a legit use for them...

> [talnicrom](#comment_25_19M1DT5vruSATEcbEczYRwCk2uPuLcATBa): Thanks!  This is exactly the kind of response I was hoping to get.  It seems that you are arguing against running a full peer on a mobile device.  However, this is not really what I was thinking.  I was thinking of making something that is just epsilon different from the existing ZeroNet proxies out there.  The only additional thing I would like to do is implement it so that user keys are not transmitted to the server.  This way ordinary people could use ZeroNet like they use any other site, save that they authenticate once for each ZeroNet session using a key instead of a password, rather than once per site using a password of their choice.

Yeah running a full node on your phone is not a great idea. "Big" projects like Tor and I2P haven't really figured out what the hell to do with mobile devices participating in their networks. Its all just experimentation. 

For remote nodes, this is why I prefer SSH Tunnels/self hosted VPN. They can establish a secure way for you to access your zeronet node at home from far away and you can transparently use them for other things. (eg. if you also have vuze/transmission web, or retroshare web, or i2p/freenet console, etc.)

They do not require additional code to be added into Zeronet and can be used right away. If you want to make it idiot proof, then caddy is the way to go because it does everything for you BUT since it uses letsencrypt older devices may not be able to use it. (not a big deal I'm talking about like 10 year old devices anyways, fat chance you even have one of them)
